DataElement.preferredName: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory-Multidimensional Fatigue GF3 Past One Month Quantity Problem Feel Too Tired to do Things I Like to Do Score 3 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated observation of how much of a problem it has been in the past one month with feeling too tired to do the things they like, using a 3 point Likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory-Multidimensional Fatigue Scale Past 30 Days Quantity Problem Feel Too Tired to do Things I Like to Do Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An 18 item component of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory is a generic symptom-specific instrument to measure fatigue in pediatric patients ages 2?18 comprised of General Fatigue, Sleep/Rest Fatigue, and Cognitive Fatigue domains._A period of time consisting of the 30 days before the present._How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number._A difficulty, disorder, or condition needing resolution._A question about whether an individual feels or felt too tired to do the things they like to do._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory-Multidimensional Fatigue Scale
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An 18 item component of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory is a generic symptom-specific instrument to measure fatigue in pediatric patients ages 2â€“18 comprised of General Fatigue, Sleep/Rest Fatigue, and Cognitive Fatigue domains.

Concepts.longName: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory-Multidimensional Fatigue Scale
Concepts.definition: An 18 item component of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory is a generic symptom-specific instrument to measure fatigue in pediatric patients ages 2-18 comprised of General Fatigue, Sleep/Rest Fatigue, and Cognitive Fatigue domains.

Property.preferredName: Past 30 Days Quantity Problem Feel Too Tired to do Things I Like to Do Score
Property.preferredDefinition: A period of time consisting of the 30 days before the present.:How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.:A difficulty, disorder, or condition needing resolution.:A question about whether an individual feels or felt too tired to do the things they like to do.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: A period of time consisting of the 30 days before the present.
How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.
A difficulty, disorder, or condition needing resolution.

Concepts.longName: Feel Too Tired to do Things I Like to Do
Concepts.definition: A question about whether an individual feels or felt too tired to do the things they like to do.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

ValueDomain.preferredName: Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory Score 3 Point Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: From time to time, but not continually or always.

Concepts.definition: From time to time, but not continually or always.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added "Sometimes" to represent the MSAS value domain.ghd.01.27.15

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer of no agreement or ability.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer of strong agreement.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer describing a great amount or extent.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Do you feel too tired to do t
ReferenceDocuments.description: Do you feel too tired to do the things you like to do

ReferenceDocuments.name: Using PRO/HRQoL Measures
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data element is part of a full set of items that comprise a PRO/HRQoL measure. The full set must be used without any changes to the questions or value set in order to retain the validity and reliability associated with the measure. Changes may not be made to these documents. In cases where retaining the question set intact to preserve the validity and reliability are not as important as advancing the science, questions may be used individually or in combination with other measure questions.
